body: @tqchen It is ready for review. For Jenkins setup, may I have the access to the OS to install JDK & maven?
a related testcase https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/tests/python/unittest/test_module_load.py
@Huyuwei is tensorflow running with XLA?

@edgarriba No, I am using the pip version tensorflow without XLA enabled.

I am not sure whether my testing method is correct, the speed comparison result is so astonishing (tensorflow too slow). Here is the code:

```python
import tensorflow as tf
import numpy as np
import time

batch = 1
in_channel = 728
in_height = 21
in_width = 21

filter_channel = in_channel
channel_multiplier = 1
filter_height = 3
filter_width = 3

stride_h = 1
stride_w = 1

with tf.device('/gpu:0'):
	input_tf = tf.Variable(tf.random_normal([batch, in_height, in_width, in_channel]))
	filter_tf = tf.Variable(tf.random_normal([filter_height, filter_width, filter_channel, channel_multiplier]))
	depth_conv_out = tf.nn.depthwise_conv2d(input_tf, filter_tf, strides=[1,stride_h,stride_w,1], padding='VALID') 

sess = tf.Session(config=tf.ConfigProto(log_device_placement=True))
sess.run(tf.global_variables_initializer())

for i in range(2):
	sess.run(depth_conv_out)

start_time = time.time()
for i in range(10000):
	sess.run(depth_conv_out)
elapsed_time = time.time() - start_time
print elapsed_time
```
Would you help check whether something is wrong? Then we may test tensorflow with XLA enabled.

It would be possible that tf code is not optimized for valid option, since same is more commonly used setting

 Another possibility is framework overhead from seas run.

If it is cuda kernel, we might be able to strip the code and plug into tvm contrib for evaluation.
using `fadd1 = tvm.module.load("./myadd.so")`, it works

Hello.

Thank you for your TVM implementation and comparison with the Tensorflow implementation. 

May I ask a few questions about the TVM implementation? 
 
1. Are there any special reasons that the batch-size is 1 in the case posted on github? In my mxnet implementation of VGG and the depth-wise VGG, I did see that depth wise convolution could perform better than VGG if the batch-size is small.

2. I also profile the tensorflow code you provided. The main reason why it is so slow is that it is transferring the data from device to host every time you call the sess.run(depth_conv_out). I modified your code to call 1000 times instead. 

Time(%)      Time     Calls       Avg       Min       Max  Name
 59.00%  15.8454s      1001  15.830ms  15.829ms  15.831ms  [CUDA memcpy DtoH]
 40.96%  10.9999s      1001  10.989ms  10.970ms  11.327ms  void tensorflow::DepthwiseConv2dGPUKernel<float, int=3, int=3, int=1>

Is it the same case in your TVM implementation? 

Thank you!

Hi everyone,

I did a study of the depth wise convolution for TF (1.2.0) and TVM. I only compare the first commit from Huyuwei, which I think it only contains forward pass. Please correct me if I am wrong.

I use nvidia profiler to collect the results. I use one K80. Batch_size = 1, channels = 128, image_size = 64*64. The brief summary are as follows (avg time is the most important):

TVM: 
program run time: 2.32315s
kernel run time by profiler: (will take more time to profile): 
Time(%)      Time     Calls       Avg       Min       Max  Name
 99.97%  3.26630s     10001  **326.60us**  321.21us  332.03us  default_function__kernel0

TF: 
program run time: 7.30s
kernel run time by profiler: (will take more time to profile): 
Time(%)      Time     Calls       Avg       Min       Max  Name
41.83%  1.81279s     10001  **181.26us**  178.97us  184.86us  void tensorflow::DepthwiseConv2dGPUKernel

This profiler only counts the code that runs on GPU. The kernel from TVM actually runs slower than TF, but because TF has more functions to run and it transfers the data from Device to Host every time you call the loop, it looks TF is way slower. 

The TVM version performs way better than I expected. 

Any comments are welcome. Thank you!

@wetliu 
Currently I am more interested in the TVM implementation performance with different parameter settings like input channel size, kernel size, and stride, not batch size. Thanks for sharing that small batch size works better for depthwise-conv network (I don't know this).

> I use nvidia profiler to collect the results. I use one K80. Batch_size = 1, channels = 128, image_size = 64*64. 

Following your settings with kernel_size = [3, 3] and stride = [1, 1], I use nvprof to do profiling on GTX 1080. The result is:
```
TVM
Time(%)      Time     Calls       Avg       Min       Max  Name
 99.80%  478.91ms     10001  47.886us  46.112us  308.64us  default_function__kernel0

TF
Time(%)      Time     Calls       Avg       Min       Max  Name
 87.13%  2.99114s     10001  299.08us  298.98us  308.16us  [CUDA memcpy DtoH]
 12.86%  441.61ms     10001  44.156us  43.616us  221.60us  void tensorflow::DepthwiseConv2dGPUKernelNHWC<float, int=3, int=3, int=1>
```
Comparing only the computation kernel part (47.886us vs 44.156us), TVM is slower than TF by 10%
The result above looks more reasonable. TVM is already very powerful if it could match the speed of human-designed kernels.

Thank you for sharing these results! TVM looks great in these cases, especially the newer GPU has better memory bandwidth. 

In fact, I think the batch-size is a great source of parallelism of the kernels when people in TF design their kernels. There are a few ways where the kernels can reuse the filters for different images in the batch too. Please increase the batch size and take a look at TVM's performance!
Yes, I need adjust TVM schedule to make use of the parallelism brought by large batch size. Will update soon.
Close for now as seems the issue is resolved
Any plan to provide this example or similars using the C++ API?

For now we will be prioritizing python examples, tvm is a c++ library and things can be built from c++ already, we would love to push forward some examples if we get contributions.

Also note that the library build with python can be loaded and run in C++ without need of python

@Huyuwei That looks great! Thank you for your work! 

Just a small question. May I confirm with the tensorflow version you are using? They are still working on the Depth wise convolution recently. The last commit was on 6/19.
@wetliu I am using tensorflow pip version 1.2.0, and all tests on GTX1080
@Huyuwei The results look good! Thank you for your reply.

with delay load, it now works on gpu and only depend on libtvm_runtime.so
what remains to do is Jenkins setup

I did a value test of the TF's depth wise convolution with TVM's depth wise convolution. I also modified the TF's default input format to (in_batch, in_channel, in_height, in_width):
tf.nn.depthwise_conv2d(input_tf, filter_tf, strides=[1,1,stride_h,stride_w], padding=padding, data_format='NCHW')

1. If the stride is larger than 1, TF's output is not consistent with TVM's output. Please double check it as I might be wrong. 

2. I also reproduced the cases where TVM is slower than TF on K80. The simple explanation is that TF's NHWC format depth wise convolution (I guess you are using this format when you compare with TVM) is faster than its NCHW format depth wise convolution. However, you are using NCHW in your TVM's tests, so the tests may not be fair to TVM. I am also curious why NCHW is slower?

3. I also do notice that there are several abnormal behavior of TVM, where the time spent on the convolution increases suddenly. I will double check and try to report back later.

@wetliu 

> strides=[1,1,stride_h,stride_w]

I remember strides = [1, stride_h, stride_w, 1] Please check it. [https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/nn/depthwise_conv2d](https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/nn/depthwise_conv2d)

Besides, TVM and TF follow different same padding conventions.

```
In TF:
pad_top = floor(pad_along_height / 2)
pad_bottom = pad_along_height - pad_top
pad_left = floor(pad_along_width / 2)
pad_right = pad_along_width - pad_left

In TVM:
pad_top = ceil(pad_along_height / 2)
pad_bottom = pad_along_height - pad_top
pad_left = ceil(pad_along_width / 2)
pad_right = pad_along_width - pad_left
```
TVM follows scipy.signal.convolve2d's same padding convention. You may modify this part when you confirm TVM's correctness with TF.

>  TF's NHWC format depth wise convolution (I guess you are using this format when you compare with TVM) is faster than its NCHW format depth wise convolution.

Yes, compared with TF's NCHW depthwise conv, TVM would be even faster. I think it's fair to compare TVM with TF's faster implementation (default NHWC format). Not clear why NHWC is faster than NCHW for TF, I feel NCHW implementation is more straightforward.

Thanks for your post. Will continue optimizing TVM schedule.

@Huyuwei It would be [1, stride_h, stride_w, 1] if the format is NHWC. It is not the case for the NCHW, where we exchange the indexes (TF will have an error and I think it is because of the data layout is different).

I am also suggesting that the NHWC may be faster for TVM! I may find out later.

A few followup comments per offline discussion

- We need to separate declaration from schedule 
- Explicitly name layout in the dataflow(since it is not NCHW)
- Change name to gpu_conv
- Make it easy for others to testout common workload, possible include a list of workload configuration in the scipt.

https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/issues/215
@Huyuwei @icemelon9 @ZihengJiang Please feel free to include more detailed examples, in comments, eventually we should put the guideline in document

SGTM, about the second part, maybe we can create an API like `dispatch_schedule([(lambda op: is_conv(op), lambda op: conv_schedule(op)), ...])`

A more generic method requires us to partition the description into small parts.

For now, it is a bit hard to have a very generic api for all schedules, mainly because the schedule is context dependent (on its inputs or parent), so we will start from specific ones, like ```schedule_conv_ewise```, which can take all conv ewise patterns, eventually when we see enough of them, we can get to a generic dispatching mechanism.

For now, creating util(like detect ewise, traverse) is good for us to start the first step

I rewrote the kernel to NHWC format (only for "valid" now) and compared with TF's result. The scheduler is simple (no shared mem/ local array). I tested on the cases where TVM's performance gets bad, except for cases where the multiplier > 1. 

1. Input: [1, 256, 96, 96], filter: [256, 1, 3, 3]
TF: 791 us
TVM: 707 us

2. [1, 256, 32, 32] 	[256, 1, 7, 7]
TF: 60.9 us
TVM: 43.1 us

@Huyuwei I also did some tests on your last commit. You've done a great job! The main limits of your code come from 1) the shared memory you allocate per block is too much that leads to limited concurrent blocks, and 2) the memory access pattern is not efficient enough (load/store efficiency). The low efficiency may result from the fact that NCHW is not a good memory layout to do the convolution efficiently.
need to build with llvm enabled, otherwise it will compile with stackvm and cannot be dumped
jar reduces to 570k for osx-cpu.

@wetliu I try dividing large image into blcoks, e.g. 96x96 into 4 blocks of 48x48. This brings 1.25x acceleration (217 us -> 165 us).
```
Input shape = (1, 256, 96, 96)
Filter shape = (256, 1, 3, 3)
Stride = (1, 1)
padding = SAME

average time of depthconv = 165.6 us
average time of depthconv + bn = 166.4 sec
average time of depthconv + bn + relu = 165.8 sec
```
Yes, depthconv + bn + relu is faster than depthconv + bn. In some cases, depthconv + bn + relu is even faster than depthconv.

### Some interesting observations

#### 1. Impact of explicit_unroll

There are three time values in each blank, referring to depthconv, depthconv + bn, depthconv + bn + relu.


| Input            | Filter         | Stride | explicit_unroll | VALID pad (us) | SAME pad (us)|
| -----------------| -------------- | ------ |:-------------:|:--------------:|:------------:|
| [1, 256, 32, 32] | [256, 1, 3, 3] | [1, 1] | True   |  27.7   26.5   25.3   | 19.6   19.8   20.0   |
| [1, 256, 32, 32] | [256, 1, 3, 3] | [1, 1] | False |  17.7   18.4   18.3    |   15.7   15.9   15.9        |
| [1, 256, 96, 96] | [256, 1, 3, 3] | [1, 1] | True          |  257.5   251.0    252.6    | 165.6   166.4   165.8     |
| [1, 256, 96, 96] | [256, 1, 3, 3] | [1, 1] | False          | 258.6   293.6   291.6         |262.8     275.8   268.5        |
 - When input channel size is 32x32, explicit_unroll = False is faster
 - When input channel size is 96x96, explicit_unroll = True is faster

#### 2. Impact of vthread
Divide 96x96 into 4 blocks of 48x48; set explicit_unroll = True

| Input            | Filter         | Stride | num_vthread_x| num_vthread_y |  SAME pad (us)|
| -----------------| -------------- | ------ |:-------:|:------:|:--------------:|
| [1, 256, 96, 96] | [256, 1, 3, 3] | [1, 1] | 1 | 1   |  200.8   200.0   200.8   |
| [1, 256, 96, 96] | [256, 1, 3, 3] | [1, 1] | 2 | 2 |   184.3   183.8   185.4        |
| [1, 256, 96, 96] | [256, 1, 3, 3] | [1, 1] | 1 | 3    | 165.6   166.4   165.8     |
| [1, 256, 96, 96] | [256, 1, 3, 3] | [1, 1] | 3 | 1     |208.8   205.7   211.3        |

- num_vthread_x = 1, num_vthread_y = 3 performs best

@tqchen It is ready for review.
I've written `reduce_mid` with dim-3 tensor. Do we need to support arbitrary shape?

I think reduce mid is a good start as it covers many of the reduction cases. For bcast it would be nice to have sugars for any dimension(which is possible because we can get ir structure in computation tree)
Close for now. Will open a new one

Also, I've done some basic speed test against the old `mx.nd.sum` and pytorch's `th.sum`. I find that the current schedule for the `tvm.sum` is faster than the `mx.nd.sum` and `th.sum` when the reduction axis is contiguous. But the speed is far slower than `th.sum`, which calls the reduction in Thrust when the reduction axis is noncontiguous.

~~Another finding is that `sum((128, 128, 128 * 24), axis=2)` is much slower than `sum((128 * 128, 128 * 24), axis=1)` while these two are doing the same thing. It should related to the `fuse_axes` I've implemented.~~ (Fixed)

I'm still figuring out how to optimize the schedule.

## Sum

All are repeated for 5 times and I use a GTX980Ti.

| Shape               | Axis |   | TVM (us) | MXNet (us) | PyTorch (us) |
|---------------------|------|---|----------|------------|--------------|
| 128, 128, 128 * 24  | 2    |   | **778**     | 1617       | 846          |
| 128, 36, 128 * 24   | 2    |   | **223**  | 242        | 477          |
| 128 * 128, 128 * 24 | 1    |   | **775**      | 1613       | 844          |
| 128, 128, 128 * 24  | 1    |   | 1649     | 2800       | **756**          |
| 128, 36, 128 * 24   | 1    |   | 479     | 1063       | **216**          |
The current fused index calculation is indeed not very optimal, and we need more robust index simplification rules. In theory the fuse could be simplified to as simple as flattened index
we don't need .so generation for the android, instead, we should create .so from client side(via something similar to tvm.contrib.xcode) and upload it

There are two separation here:

- If user only want to use TVM as runtime and load and use compiled library, only include/tvm/runtime folder is needed(with dlpack header dependency). This is the typical usecase in deploying the compiled kernels and runtime.
- If user want to use the entire compiler infra(like llvm-dev), then all the header is needed.

I usually set include path for the second one, as is what llvm-config does. So I think a basic installation script is suffice to install the first case

Given the evolution speed of the project, I think it might make sense to do the runtime installation for now, which is stable, and encourage user to set env variable path for the second one.

Optionally maybe provide tool like llvm-config to get search path

Thanks for the review, @tqchen! Right now we are definitely making use of the compiler infra, and our current workflow looks like this:

1. Build TVM using conda (I can submit this packaging too if it would be useful)
2. Install TVM in a conda environment using the conda package
3. Build our stuff

In this workflow, setting include directly directly to source directory doesn't really work.

Maybe we can have two install modes/a configure flag to toggle the install mode? One which is runtime only, and the other installs everything.
The installation mode sounds good to me. Yes, a conda installation would definitely be useful

There are two types for std::string in TVM.

- kStr  which is the type we need and can be casted safely to  TVMType implicitly
- kBytes which represent the binary blob(cannot be casted to TVMType)

In python side, string_types will be translated to kStr, while  bytearray(for both py2, py3) are translated to kBytes.

This error is caused by passing bytes into type field of var(which I don't know why)
This turned out to be user error. I'll file a different bug explaining why.

I agree that a search algorithm that searches the following priority makes sense
- LD_LIBRARY_PATH
- inplace 
- installation location (possible cmake path, we don't have to ask cmake to dump to lib)

Having the LD_LIBRARY_PATH as highest priority enables configurability by allowing user to simply set it before importing tvm to point to different versions. 
We could also have an environment variable TVM_LIBRARY_PATH,  which have the highest priority, to allow python script to quickly change the path by setting this variable
do you want to include the dev mode as well? or include the discussed change in https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/issues/281?

As for make system, for now i think we can keep the makefile. In general i favor cmake on complicated builds, but makefile offers some flexiblity in terms minimum dependency and when building rules are very simple, like build runtime on a dev board which may not have right version of cmake available
I think I'll do this all together, probably makes the most sense.

Why do we need BuildConfig? Usually the buld config function is suffice for most purposes

In order to pass *with* conditions such as unroll to tvm.build using mxnet-tvm.bind which is built on top of tvm, it's not possible to pass the conditions all the way to tvm.build without BuildConfig.
You can call with build_config, which will have the same effect

I think if the shape are constant, you only need a pad step, which is like out_grad_cond, but only requires check for four boundary conditions. This is like the pad step you might have in the input padding, and can be done efficiently if they are cached to temp.
